dataset.name: pharmacy_copilot_pharmacist_eval_v1
dataset.description: Gold pharmacist scenarios for LLM evaluation (enriched for deterministic scoring).

failure_cases.question: 5-year-old (18 kg) with acute otitis media. What is the amoxicillin dose and volume using 400 mg/5 mL suspension?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": 810,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": 10.1,
  "frequency": "q12h",
  "max_daily_mg": 4000,
  "rounding": "rounding to practical mL is acceptable",
  "calc_rule": "High-dose 80-90 mg/kg/day regimen; BID (q12h) frequency; Per-dose dose calculated as (18 kg * 80 mg/kg) / 5 mL (80 mg/mL); rounding to 10 mL OK; Max daily dose acknowledged",
  "citations": ["lexi-amoxicillin-2018#dosage"],
  "notes": "Uses high-dose 80-90 mg/kg/day regimen for pediatric AOM; BID (q12h) frequency; Per-dose ≈810 mg for 18 kg; Volume ≈10.1 mL
failure_cases.expected_answer: Amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided q12h → 810 mg per dose (≈10.1 mL of 400 mg/5 mL), round to 10 mL per dose; max 4 g/day.
key_points_missing: No renal adjustment if normal function

key_points_found: Volume ≈10.1 mL from 400 mg/5 mL (80 mg/mL); rounding to 10 mL OK
key_points_missing: No renal adjustment if normal function

failure_cases.question: 12 kg child with fever: acetaminophen dose and volume using 160 mg/5 mL?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": 180,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": 5.625,
  "frequency": "q6h",
  "max_daily_mg": 1440,
  "max_daily_mL": null,
  "rounding": "rounded to one decimal",
  "calc_rule": "15 mg/kg per dose, q4-6h, target q6h, 32 mg/mL",
  "citations": ["lexi-acetaminophen-2018#peds-dosing", "lexi-acetaminophen-2018#max"],
  "notes": "Pediatric dosing; liquid form"
}
failure_cases.expected_answer: Acetaminophen 15 mg/kg/dose q6h (range 10–15 mg/kg q4–6h) → 180 mg per dose ≈5.6 mL of 160 mg/5 mL; max 75 mg/kg/day (900 mg), and ≤4 g absolute.
key_points_missing: q4–6h acceptable; target q6h in calc
q4–6h acceptable; target q6h in calc

failure_cases.question: 12 kg child with fever: ibuprofen dose and volume using 100 mg/5 mL?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": 120,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": 6.0,
  "frequency": "q6-8h",
  "max_daily_mg": 480,
  "rounding": "round to nearest 0.1 mL",
  "calc_rule": "10 mg/kg per dose, maximum 40 mg/kg/day",
  "citations": ["lexi-ibuprofen-2018#peds-dosing", "lexi-ibuprofen-2018#max"],
  "notes": "12 kg child with fever: 120 mg ibuprofen per dose (6 mL of 100 mg/5 mL suspension), q6-8h; maximum daily dose 480 mg; contraindicated in children under 6 months and use with caution in renal/dehydration risk"
}
failure_cases.expected_answer: Ibuprofen 10 mg/kg/dose q6–8h → 120 mg per dose (6 mL of 100 mg/5 mL); max 40 mg/kg/day (480 mg). Avoid if <6 months or dehydrated/renal issues.

failure_cases.question: Elderly patient with nonvalvular AF: 82 years, 58 kg, SCr 1.6 mg/dL. What apixaban dose?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": 2.5,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": null,
  "frequency": "BID",
  "max_daily_mg": null,
  "rounding": "Not applicable (tablets)",
  "calc_rule": "Dose reduction criteria: 2 of 3: age ≥80 years, weight ≤60 kg, or serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL",
  "citations": ["lexi-apixaban-2018#dosing-nvaf"],
  "notes": "Avoid strong CYP3A4/P-gp inhibitors/inducers and assess hepatic impairment."
failure_cases.expected_answer: Apixaban 2.5 mg BID (meets 2 of 3: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, SCr ≥1.5). Avoid with strong CYP3A4/P-gp inhibitors.

failure_cases.question: 85 kg adult with acute DVT: What is the enoxaparin treatment dose (normal renal function)?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": 85,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": null,
  "frequency": "q12h",
  "max_daily_mg": null,
  "rounding": "Rounded to nearest whole number",
  "calc_rule": "1 mg/kg q12h (primary regimen) or 1.5 mg/kg q24h (alternative), adjusted for renal function (CrCl <30: 1 mg/kg q24h)",
  "citations": ["lexi-enoxaparin-2018#dosing"],
  "notes": "Renal adjustment for CrCl <30 may be necessary"
}
failure_cases.expected_answer: Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h → 85 mg per dose (or 1.5 mg/kg once daily as alternative). If CrCl <30 mL/min: 1 mg/kg once daily.

failure_cases.question: Type 2 diabetes patient with eGFR 28 mL/min/1.73 m². Can we use metformin?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": null,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": null,
  "frequency": null,
  "max_daily_mg": null,
  "rounding": "Not applicable",
  "calc_rule": "Contraindicated if eGFR <30, avoid initiation if 30-45, continue with dose reduction and monitoring",
  "citations": ["lexi-metformin-2018#renal"],
  "notes": "Metformin is contraindicated in eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m², and should be avoided in initiation for eGFR 30-45. If continued, dose reduction and monitoring of renal function is necessary."
failure_cases.expected_answer: No—contraindicated at eGFR <30. If 30–45, generally avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce dose and monitor. Avoid in hepatic impairment.
key_points_missing: 30–45: avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce & monitor
30–45: avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce & monitor

  "rounding": "Not applicable",
  "calc_rule": "Avoid use if eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to inadequate urinary concentrations and increased toxicity risk (lexi-nitrofurantoin-2018#renal)",
  "citations": ["lexi-nitrofurantoin-2018#renal"],
  "notes": "Avoid nitrofurantoin in eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to efficacy and toxicity concerns. Common contraindications include significant renal dysfunction (lexi-nitrofurantoin-2018#contra)."

failure_cases.expected_answer: Avoid nitrofurantoin when eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to low urinary levels and toxicity risk.

failure_cases.question: Patient on warfarin needs TMP-SMX for UTI. Any interaction and what should we do?
failure_cases.generated_answer:
{
  "dose_per_dose_mg": null,
  "volume_per_dose_mL": null,
  "frequency": "q12h",
  "max_daily_mg": null,
  "rounding": "round to nearest 5mg",
  "calc_rule": "Avoid TMP-SMX due to major interaction (CYP2C9 inhibition and gut flora changes), leading to increased INR. If used, reduce warfarin dose and increase INR monitoring.",
  "citations": ["lexi-warfarin-2018#ddi-tmp-smx"],
  "notes": "Avoid TMP-SMX with warfarin; close INR monitoring with dose reduction if used."
}
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction (CYP2C9 inhibition + gut flora). Avoid if possible; otherwise increase INR monitoring and reduce warfarin dose.

key_points_found: Action: avoid or close INR monitoring with dose reduction

failure_cases.question: Patient on atorvastatin needs clarithromycin. What’s the risk and action?

  "notes": "Avoid coadministration of clarithromycin with atorvastatin due to increased risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis; if unavoidable, hold or use the lowest dose with close monitoring"
}
failure_cases.expected_answer: Major interaction (strong CYP3A4 inhibitor). Avoid coadministration; if unavoidable, hold atorvastatin or limit to the lowest dose and monitor for myopathy.

key_points_found: Action: avoid; if unavoidable hold or use lowest dose with monitoring

question.question: 5-year-old (18 kg) with acute otitis media. What is the amoxicillin dose and volume using 400 mg/5 mL suspension?
question.expected_answer: Amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided q12h → 810 mg per dose (≈10.1 mL of 400 mg/5 mL), round to 10 mL per dose; max 4 g/day.
answer_key_points: Volume ≈10.1 mL from 400 mg/5 mL (80 mg/mL); rounding to 10 mL OK
No renal adjustment if normal function

oracle_context.text: Pediatric AOM first-line: amoxicillin 80–90 mg/kg/day PO divided q12h for 5–10 days; typical max daily dose ~4,000 mg.
Amoxicillin oral suspension 400 mg/5 mL = 80 mg/mL; use oral syringe; rounding to practical mL is acceptable.
Adult acute bacterial sinusitis regimens (e.g., 500 mg TID or 875 mg BID) differ from pediatric AOM dosing.

question.question: 12 kg child with fever: acetaminophen dose and volume using 160 mg/5 mL?
question.expected_answer: Acetaminophen 15 mg/kg/dose q6h (range 10–15 mg/kg q4–6h) → 180 mg per dose ≈5.6 mL of 160 mg/5 mL; max 75 mg/kg/day (900 mg), and ≤4 g absolute.
answer_key_points: q4–6h acceptable; target q6h in calc

oracle_context.text: Acetaminophen 10–15 mg/kg/dose PO q4–6h PRN fever/pain; do not exceed 75 mg/kg/day or 4,000 mg/day; ~5 doses/24h.
Common liquid: 160 mg/5 mL (32 mg/mL). Use weight-based dosing and state per-dose mL.
Rectal suppository dosing differs from oral liquids and is not used for this calculation.

question.question: Elderly patient with nonvalvular AF: 82 years, 58 kg, SCr 1.6 mg/dL. What apixaban dose?
question.expected_answer: Apixaban 2.5 mg BID (meets 2 of 3: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, SCr ≥1.5). Avoid with strong CYP3A4/P-gp inhibitors.

gold.calc_rule: If ≥2 of {age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, SCr ≥1.5} → 2.5 mg BID

oracle_context.text: NVAF: apixaban 5 mg BID; reduce to 2.5 mg BID if the patient has ≥2 of: age ≥80 years, weight ≤60 kg, or serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL.
Avoid with strong dual CYP3A4/P-gp inhibitors/inducers; assess hepatic impairment.
VTE treatment: 10 mg BID x7 days then 5 mg BID—this regimen does not apply to NVAF dosing decisions.

question.question: 85 kg adult with acute DVT: What is the enoxaparin treatment dose (normal renal function)?
question.expected_answer: Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h → 85 mg per dose (or 1.5 mg/kg once daily as alternative). If CrCl <30 mL/min: 1 mg/kg once daily.

oracle_context.text: Acute DVT treatment (normal renal function): enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h (preferred) or 1.5 mg/kg SC once daily (alternative).
If CrCl <30 mL/min, use 1 mg/kg SC once daily and monitor anti-Xa as indicated.
VTE prophylaxis doses (e.g., 40 mg SC daily) are not treatment doses and should not be used here.

question.question: Type 2 diabetes patient with eGFR 28 mL/min/1.73 m². Can we use metformin?
question.expected_answer: No—contraindicated at eGFR <30. If 30–45, generally avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce dose and monitor. Avoid in hepatic impairment.
answer_key_points: 30–45: avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce & monitor

gold.renal_adjustment: eGFR 30–45: avoid initiation; reduce if continuing; monitor

oracle_context.text: Metformin: contraindicated if eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m². At 30–45, generally avoid initiation; if continuing, reduce dose and monitor renal function.
Avoid in hepatic impairment or conditions predisposing to lactic acidosis; manage iodinated contrast per eGFR.
Older conservative thresholds (e.g., avoid if CrCl <60) are superseded by eGFR-based guidance.

question.question: Uncomplicated cystitis: Should we use nitrofurantoin if eGFR is 25?
question.expected_answer: Avoid nitrofurantoin when eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to low urinary levels and toxicity risk.

oracle_context.text: Nitrofurantoin: avoid when eGFR/CrCl <30 mL/min due to inadequate urinary concentrations and increased toxicity risk.
Contraindications include late-term pregnancy (at term) and significant renal dysfunction.
Prophylaxis regimens (e.g., low-dose at bedtime) do not override renal cutoffs for acute cystitis treatment.

question.question: Patient on warfarin needs TMP-SMX for UTI. Any interaction and what should we do?
question.expected_answer: Major interaction (CYP2C9 inhibition + gut flora). Avoid if possible; otherwise increase INR monitoring and reduce warfarin dose.
answer_key_points: Action: avoid or close INR monitoring with dose reduction

interactions.action: avoid if possible; otherwise increase INR monitoring and reduce warfarin dose

oracle_context.text: TMP-SMX markedly increases warfarin effect via CYP2C9 inhibition and gut-flora changes; expect INR rise. Prefer alternatives; if used, reduce warfarin dose and increase INR monitoring.
Cephalexin has minimal effect on warfarin relative to TMP-SMX; management differs.

question.question: Patient on atorvastatin needs clarithromycin. What’s the risk and action?
question.expected_answer: Major interaction (strong CYP3A4 inhibitor). Avoid coadministration; if unavoidable, hold atorvastatin or limit to the lowest dose and monitor for myopathy.
answer_key_points: Action: avoid; if unavoidable hold or use lowest dose with monitoring

interactions.action: avoid coadministration; if unavoidable, hold atorvastatin or use lowest dose with monitoring

oracle_context.text: Clarithromycin is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor; coadministration increases atorvastatin levels and myopathy/rhabdomyolysis risk. Avoid; if unavoidable, hold or use the lowest dose with close monitoring.
Azithromycin has little CYP3A4 inhibition and is not a suitable proxy for clarithromycin interactions.

question.question: Starting linezolid in a patient on sertraline. Is this safe?
question.expected_answer: Major interaction: risk of serotonin syndrome (linezolid has MAOI activity). Avoid; if benefits outweigh risks, withhold SSRI or monitor very closely.
answer_key_points: Action: avoid; or stop SSRI/close monitoring if unavoidable

interactions.action: avoid combination; if unavoidable, withhold SSRI or monitor closely

oracle_context.text: Linezolid has reversible MAOI activity and may precipitate serotonin syndrome with SSRIs. Avoid combination; if benefits outweigh risks, withhold SSRI and monitor closely.
No serotonergic interaction with penicillins; this is not relevant to SSRI risk.

question.question: Patient on digoxin will start amiodarone. What’s the interaction management?
question.expected_answer: Major interaction (P-gp inhibition). Reduce digoxin dose by ~30–50% and monitor levels/ECG.
answer_key_points: Action: reduce dose ~30–50% + monitor levels and ECG

interactions.action: reduce digoxin dose by ~30–50% and monitor serum levels and ECG

oracle_context.text: Amiodarone inhibits P-gp, increasing digoxin exposure. Reduce digoxin dose by ~30–50% and monitor serum levels, renal function, and ECG.
Verapamil also raises digoxin via P-gp inhibition, but this does not address amiodarone-specific management.
